Expectation1: Help out during difficult times or emergencies.
Situation1: You get a I04antic call I04om your I04iend whose car has broken down on the side of the highway late at night, and they need you to come get them immediately.
Expectation2: Meet sales targets set by management
Situation2: On the final day of the quarter, the team must hit the cumulative target to avoid penalties and secure bonuses.
Story: My phone buzzed just as I was about to dial the next number on my call list. It was Jamie, my best friend, her voice shaky and urgent. “My car broke down on the highway. Can you come get me? Please, I’m scared.” I glanced at the clock—9:45 p.m. Only two hours left in the quarter, and I was still three sales short of my target. The manager’s words echoed in my mind: “If we don’t hit the numbers tonight, no bonuses. No exceptions.” I could hear the desperation in Jamie’s voice, but I also felt the weight of my team’s expectations, the pressure to perform, the fear of letting everyone down. My headset felt heavier than ever. I stared at the blinking cursor on my screen, torn between the friend who needed me and the job that demanded everything I had left. My heart pounded as I tried to figure out what to do, caught between loyalty and obligation, knowing that whatever I chose, something important would be left behind.
